Award.AwardTitle: Representation Theory of W-Algebras, Rational Cherednik Algebras, and Quantized Quiver Varieties
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project deals with representation theory, the branch of mathematics concerned with studying linear symmetries. Symmetries often form algebraic structures, such as associative algebras. The algebras studied in this project all have a geometric nature and originate from quantum physics. The goal is to understand representations of a given algebra, meaning ways the algebra can be represented as linear symmetries of something else. The basic building blocks here are irreducible representations, and a large part of this project deals with describing possible irreducible representations and computing important invariants, such as their dimensions. A second important question to be addressed in this project is understanding how more complicated representations may be built from irreducible representations.

The project is devoted to the study of the representation theory W-algebras, rational Cherednik algebras, and quantized quiver varieties. For W-algebras, the investigator plans to classify the finite dimensional irreducible representations. For rational Cherednik algebras, the investigator plans to compute the number of simple objects in associated category O with given support. For quantized quiver varieties, the investigator plans to compute the characters of finite dimensional irreducible representations, study the structure of the corresponding category O, and produce derived equivalences as Ringel dualities for standardly stratified structures. This includes computing the dimensions of supports of irreducible modules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Representation theory studies linear symmetries of mathematical objects and is closely connected to other subjects in Mathematics (such as Geometry and Number theory) and Physics (quantum Mechanics and Field theory). Symmetry is usually understood as a realization of some algebraic structure (an associative algebra,  a group or a Lie algebra) by matrices or, more generally, linear operators in some vector space. Two main questions in Representation theory include:

1)  understanding the structure of irreducible representations  (basic building blocks for arbitrary representations) and

2) determining the ways how a general representation can be built from irreducible ones.

Intellectual merit. The project concentrated on the study of representations of algebras with origins in Geometry and Physics.  The algebras of interest mostly appeared as quantizations (non-commutative deformations) of singular symplectic varieties, which is a remarkable class of algebraic varieties. The investigator has written a sequence of papers studying the structure of categories of representations for quantizations of singular symplectic varieties and equivalences between them, which has to do with question 2) above. In special cases -- for quantizations of quiver varieties -- these techniques allowed the investigator to answer basic questions about irreducible representations, including computing the number of those.  Besides, the investigator has achieved a significant progress on several classical topics of the representation theory of Lie groups and Lie algebras, namely, on a series of questions related to Orbit method. The investigator has also obtained several new important results on the representation theory in positive characterstic including formulas for characters of irreducibles (joint with Bezrukavnikov and with Elias).  

Broader impact: the PI is or has been supervising six graduate students working on  topics related to the project. The PI has written several survey texts and gave numerous lectures aimed at undergraduate and graudate students. He also coorganized several graudate student seminars.
